items.title: Digging into explicit resource management
items.content:
#â€‹663 â€” November 16, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Prettier 3.1 Released â€” The popular opinionated code formatter has a new release including support for the new control flow syntax in Angular 17 plus a new, experimental formatting option for ternary expressions (as in x ? y : z) explained in more depth in "A curious case of theÂ ternaries."

Alex Rattray

ğŸ¤” With an aim to making code formatting even faster, Prettier's co-creator has put up a $10k bounty for any Rust project that passes >95% of Prettier's tests.

Exploring Explicit Resource Management in JS â€” A practical look at the idea of explicit resource management, an idea both currently at stage 3 in TC39 (and partly supported in TypeScript 5.2) that makes it easier to â€˜clean upâ€™ resources once they are no longer used orÂ needed.

Ilia Pozdnyakov

Build Interactive, Live Video Applications with AmazonÂ IVS â€” Amazon Interactive Video Service (Amazon IVS) allows developers to create dynamic video experiences, such as collaborative real-time livestreams. Check out the new ivs.rocks to find code samples, demos, and other resources. Click here to getÂ started.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

On HTML Web Components â€” â€œWith web components, you might even say Reactâ€™s component model is being ported to the browser. But itâ€™s being done in a way that works to enhance how the web already works, not replaceÂ itâ€.

Jim Nielsen

A Review of Lightweight JavaScript Frameworks â€” This overview is targeted at Django (i.e. Python) developers but if you, too, want to avoid larger frameworks like React or Angular, you might appreciate this look at numerous alternatives from Stimulus and htmx to more oblique options like LaravelÂ Livewire.

Michael Yin

  • ğŸ¥³ AWS is celebrating a huge release with v6 of the AWS Amplify JavaScript library which includes full support for Next.js App Router and ServerÂ Actions.

  • ğŸŒ Node.js TSC member Yagiz Nizipli is suggesting using Biome for code formatting in Node, since ESLint has deprecated its core formatting rules.

  • ğŸ‘¾ The winners of React Jam, a recent React-based game development contest, have been revealed. An entry I enjoyed was useChess, a set of chess-based puzzles.

  • â–¶ï¸ If you've wondered what the big deal is about Astro, James Q Quick went on the Software Engineering Daily podcast and explained Astro pretty well.

  • ğŸµ Someone's recorded â–¶ï¸Â aÂ rap music video about TypeScript..

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v21.2.0 (Current)

  • visx 3.5 â€“ D3-based visualization primitives forÂ React.

  • fx 31.0 â€“ Powerful terminal JSONÂ viewer.

  • Astro 3.5, Ember 5.4, and Prisma 5.6.

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

67 Browser-Based Debugging Tricks â€” A list of useful, â€˜not-obviousâ€™ hacks to get the most out of the browserâ€™s DevTools. Assumes a reasonable existing understanding of saidÂ tools.

Alan Norbauer

Exploring V8's Strings: Implementation and Optimizations â€” Note: This is very technical and most JavaScript developers do not need to go this deep. That aside, this is a fantastic look under the covers of how the V8 engine handles strings, including the optimizations used that allow it to go toe to toe with languages likeÂ C++.

Ilia Pozdnyakov

JavaScript Scratchpad for VSÂ Code â€” Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring/testing JavaScript with edit-continue experience to see realtime execution and runtimeÂ values.

Wallaby Team sponsor

â–¶Â Â An Overview of Angular 17's New Built-In Control Flow â€” Angular 17 was released last week and a significant enhancement was support for a new syntax in templates that looks and feels moreÂ JavaScript-y.

Dmytro Mezhenskyi

Moving Back to React (from Preact) â€” Preact felt like a logical, lightweight choice to this team at one time, but theyâ€™ve switched to React for better compatibility with Next.js, among other things. Their page weight is up slightly, but they feel the tradeoff is worthÂ it.

Ante BariÄ‡ (Dailyâ€¤Dev)

My Journey to 3x Faster Builds: Trimming Barrel File Imports â€” â€œI maintain a small frontend application (4K LOC) which uses Vite as the compiler. The production build, using npm run build, was taking 26 secs on Github Actions. It seemed awfully slow for such a small application. I decided to investigateÂ why.â€

Ramana Venkata

Can Bun Eat Nodeâ€™s 'Lunch'? â€” An experiment in migrating a codebase (a restaurant voting app called Lunch) from Node over to Bun and seeing how itÂ fares.

Jeffrey Carl Faden

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and Work #LikeABosch

Bosch sponsor

How to Use NPM Packages Outside of Node â€” Learn how to run NPM packages in â€˜other placesâ€™ like serverless platforms, the browser, andÂ beyond.

George MacKerron (Neon)

What I Learned Building an Audio Plugins System for the Web
Ben Wiley

Rust for JavaScript Developers: An Overview of Testing
Joshua Mo

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

gsplat.js: A Gaussian Splatting Library â€” Gaussian splatting is an increasingly popular graphics rendering techniques where rather than render millions of tiny, textured triangles in a scene, you get a more wild paintball-like splatter fest, where each paintball creates a smooth, colorful blob instead of a rigid shape. This demo is both simple andÂ striking.

Dylan Ebert

Reveal.js 5.0: The HTML Presentation Framework â€” A way to build presentations using standard Web technologies. The projectâ€™s homepage is, itself, such a presentation. v5.0 adds support for â€˜scroll modeâ€™ which essentially turns presentations into more typically scrolling Web experiences â€“ demo.

Hakim El Hattab

ğŸ–ï¸ Marker.io: Collect Bug Reports With Annotations & Session Replay â€” Collect feedback on live websites. Get dev-friendly bug reports with screenshots, URLs, console logs & sessionÂ replay.

Marker.io sponsor

Datasheet Grid: An Airtable-like React Component â€” If youâ€™ve got an array of objects and you want a way for users to manipulate them, this is for you. Itâ€™s not going to replace a spreadsheet or an extensive data grid framework, but itâ€™s a mature solution featuring smooth animations, virtualized rows/columns, keyboard navigation, andÂ more.

Nicolas Keller

Perfect Freehand: A Library for Creating Better 'Freehand' Lines â€” You can try it out here. Makes your e-signature not look like chicken scratch! Might be useful for drawingÂ apps.

Steve Ruiz

Wild Wild Path v5: Object Property Paths with Wildcards and Regexps â€” A 'wild' way to access properties in objects (which can be deeply nested) by way of string based queries that support wildcards andÂ regexes. The examples help communicate theÂ idea.

ehmicky

@storybook-test: More Streamlined and Powerful Storybook Testing â€” @storybook/test consolidates the API of @storybook/jest and @storybook/testing-library into a new, single package, powered byÂ Vitest.

Kasper Peulen

  • Marked 10.0 â€“ Markdown parser andÂ compiler. There's also marked-terminal 6.1 which lets you render Marked-processed Markdown on theÂ terminal.

  • HumanizeDuration.js 3.31.0 â€“ Turn milliseconds into textual durations in numerous naturalÂ languages.

  • actions/github-script 7.0 â€“ Script the GitHub API in GitHubÂ Actions.

  • Plasmo v0.84.0 â€“ "Like Next.js for browserÂ extensions."

  • PDFKit 0.14.0 â€“ PDF generation for Node and browser.

  • React Joyride 2.7 â€“ Create guided tours in yourÂ apps.

Job Listing

Full Stack TypeScript Software Engineer - [Remote Europe] â€” Marker.io is a visual bug-reporting tool for the web. Join our dev team and work remotely (Stack: Node.js, Vue.js &Â MongoDB).

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œWhen you choose a language, youâ€™re choosing more than a set of technical trade-offs â€“ youâ€™re choosing aÂ community.â€

___
Joshua Bloch

items.title: Angular is back
items.content:
#â€‹662 â€” November 9, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Reintroducing Angular with Angular v17 â€” Angular first appeared in the shape of AngularJS in 2010 and helped launch a wave of large-scale JavaScript frameworks. Angular remains popular in many use cases but is often overlooked in favor of newer options. v17 takes a leap forward in both features and vision, with the team rebranding Angular and repositioning it as a modern solution:

  • Angular.dev is an all-new docs site and home for the project (the new guides look fantastic). It's in beta till Angular v18 is released â€“ you can learn more about itÂ here.
  • Hydration is now production ready.
  • Vite and esbuild are the default for new projects.
  • Improved support for creating server side apps.
  • New, improved built-in control flow to make code lessÂ verbose.
  • Google pulled out all the stops for â–¶ï¸ the 'Special Angular Event' â€“ an hour of talks, interviews and discussions to bring you up toÂ speed.

Minko Gechev and the Angular Team

Bare Metal JavaScript: The JavaScript Virtual Machine with MiÅ¡ko Hevery â€” Learn how high-level JavaScript turns into low-level CPU instructions. Build up your mental model of JavaScript's performance characteristics through understanding the JavaScript Virtual machine under theÂ hood!

Frontend Masters sponsor

Mastering DOM Manipulation with Plain JavaScript â€” A mega collection of hundreds of examples of doing things like selecting text, manipulating elements, resizing things, scrolling, and such â€“ all by using the DOM and browser APIs with no external libraries. You Might Not Need jQuery is another classic resource in a similarÂ vein.

Phuoc Nguyen

â–¶Â Â Why Signals Are Better Than React Hooks â€” When Preactâ€™s Marvin Hagemeister pops up in the comments saying â€œthis is by far the best video about signals and why they are so exciting. I love the way you demonstrate it by coding along and moving an app over to signals,â€ it should bump a video up to the top of the Watch Later playlist.

Web Dev Simplified

  • ğŸ‘€ Nicholas C. Zakas shares a look at what's coming in ESLint v9.0. The first alpha is due in a month orÂ two.

  • âš›ï¸ React has landed a commit adding sourcemaps for prod buildÂ artifacts.

  • ğŸ†š VS Code will soon support moving editors into floatingÂ windows.

RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.3 RC â€“ Final due soon, but you get import attributes, resolution-mode in import types, interactive inlay hints for types, and improvements to narrowing in a few extra cases.

  • It's a strong week for testing tool releases, so they're all in one place: TestCafe v3.4.0, Cypress 13.5, Nightwatch.js 3.3, and React Testing LibraryÂ 14.1.

  • Deno 1.38 â€“ Many smaller improvements, including far faster JSXÂ transformation.

  • Bun v1.0.10 â€“ Faster node:http and bugÂ fixes.

  • tsx 4.0 â€“ Node.js enhanced to run TypeScript / ESMÂ files.

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Do a JS to TypeScript Conversion â€” Chris, who led the conversion of a 150k LOC app to TypeScript, addresses a common question: do-it-as-you-go or follow the dependencyÂ graph?

Chris Krycho

Exploring the Headless Component Pattern for Composing React UIs â€” An engineer at Atlassian takes us on a thorough and practical journey into the concept of headless components and the pattern of having reusable logic and behavior separate from the presentation of UIÂ elements.

Juntao Qiu

ğŸ“ Calling JavaScript Devs! Sentry Launch Week is Coming. JoinÂ Online

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â 8 Talks from JetBrains' JavaScript Day 2023 â€” JavaScript Day is an annual virtual event featuring a handful of talks on diverse JS related topics. This year, Romulo Cintra shows us how TC39 works on language proposals, Stefan Baumgartner spoke about the lies we tell ourselves using TypeScript, and more.

JetBrains

Writing Components That Work in Any Framework â€” Looks at why web components can be difficult to adopt, and shows how using a higher-level library can let us â€œeasily write components that workÂ everywhereâ€.

Andrico Karoulla

Build a Lightweight Code Generator with TypeScript and JSON Imports
John Ruble

Deploying a Vue Application with Netlify and GitHub
Ezekiel Lawson (Telerik)

Don't Disable Buttons, Do This..
Chris Ferdinandi

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Moveable: A Library for Dragging, Resizing, Scaling and More â€” If you want to offer up physical manipulation of elements (warping, pinching, rotating, etc.) this library could help. Its homepage is a fun self-demo and there are packages for integrations with commonÂ frameworks.

Younkue Choi

ğŸ”¥ Need to Eliminate Tech Debt Without Falling into DependencyÂ Hell? â€” Upgrade seamlessly and let us tackle tech debt with our fixed-cost, monthly maintenance service (starting atÂ $2k/month).

UpgradeJS | Tech Debt Services sponsor

ğŸ–¼ Â image-dimensions: Get the Dimensions of Images â€” Sindreâ€™s latest creation is a simple but comprehensive one. A way to get the size (as width and height in pixels) for JPEG, PNG, APNG, and GIFs in any modern JSÂ environment.

Sindre Sorhus

main-thread-scheduling 9.0: Consistently Responsive Apps While Staying on the Main Thread â€” An easier alternative to Web Workers that uses the approach of stopping heavy tasks on the main thread from executing when the user interacts with the UI. This new version adds afterFrame (like requestAnimationFrame but called after frame drawing has rendered), queueTask, and extensions toÂ promises.

Antonio Stoilkov

React Components for the Google Maps JavaScript API â€” react-google-maps is the â€˜first Google-sponsored libraryâ€™ for integrating Google Maps JavaScript API components into a ReactÂ app.

Mike Pegg (Google Cloud)

capture-website 4.0: Capture Screenshots of Websites â€” A Puppeteer wrapper to capture screenshots of site from Node or theÂ command-line.

Sindre Sorhus

Never Stop Learning and Work #LikeABosch â€” At Bosch, you always keep growing. Upskill yourself into countless new roles, positions and opportunities. LearnÂ more.

Bosch sponsor

âŒ˜K-sv: A Fast, Composable, Unstyled Command Menu for Svelte â€” A port of âŒ˜K, a React-based command menuÂ component.

huntabyte

  • Vuetify v3.4 â€“ Vue component framework.

  • MiniSearch 6.2 â€“ In-memory fulltext search engine.Â (Demo.)

  • TanStack Form 0.9 â€“ Headless type-safe form stateÂ management.

  • Dependency Cruiser v15.2 â€“ Tool to validate and visualizeÂ dependencies.

  • Valtio v1.12.0 â€“ Proxy state made simple. Plus it has a fantasticÂ homepage.

  • Helmet 7.1 â€“ Secure Express apps with HTTPÂ headers.

  • Rollup.js 4.3 â€“ ES moduleÂ bundler.

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œThe first 90% of the code accounts for the first 90% of the development time. The remaining 10% of the code accounts for the other 90% of the development time.â€

___
Tom Cargill

ğŸš€Â Everyone's gone to the moon..

Spacekit.js: A Library for Creating 3D Space Visualizations â€” Not just any old 3D space, but actual space â€“ think planets, stars, and meteors. A library like this comes, of course, with many examples to try. GitHubÂ repo.

Ian Webster

This new version adds afterFrame (like requestAnimationFrame but called after frame drawing has rendered), queueTask, and extensions toÂ promises.
Antonio Stoilkov 


  
  
React Components for the Google Maps JavaScript API â€” react-google-maps is the â€˜first Google-sponsored libraryâ€™ for integrating Google Maps JavaScript API components into a ReactÂ app.
Mike Pegg (Google Cloud) 


  
  
capture-website 4.0: Capture Screenshots of Websites â€” A Puppeteer wrapper to capture screenshots of site from Node or theÂ command-line.
Sindre Sorhus 





  
  
Never Stop Learning and Work #LikeABosch â€” At Bosch, you always keep growing. Upskill yourself into countless new roles, positions and opportunities. LearnÂ more.
Bosch sponsor





  





  
  
âŒ˜K-sv: A Fast, Composable, Unstyled Command Menu for Svelte â€” A port of âŒ˜K, a React-based command menuÂ component.
huntabyte 




Vuetify v3.4 â€“ Vue component framework.
MiniSearch 6.2 â€“ In-memory fulltext search engine.Â (Demo.)
TanStack Form 0.9 â€“ Headless type-safe form stateÂ management.
Dependency Cruiser v15.2 â€“ Tool to validate and visualizeÂ dependencies.
Valtio v1.12.0 â€“ Proxy state made simple. Plus it has a fantasticÂ homepage.
Helmet 7.1 â€“ Secure Express apps with HTTPÂ headers.
Rollup.js 4.3 â€“ ES moduleÂ bundler.





NOTABLE QUOTABLE





  
â€œThe first 90% of the code accounts for the first 90% of the development time. The remaining 10% of the code accounts for the other 90% of the development time.â€
___
Tom Cargill



ğŸš€Â Everyone's gone to the moon..




  





  
  
Spacekit.js: A Library for Creating 3D Space Visualizations â€” Not just any old 3D space, but actual space â€“ think planets, stars, and meteors. A library like this comes, of course, with many examples to try. GitHubÂ repo.
Ian Webster

items.title: Big news for both Next.js and Remix
items.content:
#â€‹661 â€” November 2, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Next.js 14 Released â€” Unveiled at last weekâ€™s Next.js Conf, v14 caused a lot of community discussion (not least on Hacker News), largely surrounding Server Actions being declared stable and the 'backend-meets-frontend' opportunities this opens up. A new partial prerendering feature is also in preview, allowing for dynamic responses but with the speed of an initial staticÂ response.

Lee Robinson and Tim Neutkens

ğŸ’¡ The New Stack has an overview of the release, and Focus Reactive has a (highly visual) recap of Next.js Conf itself â€“ recommended if you didn't watch theÂ stream.

SDKs & OpenAPI Specs in Minutes Using Zod, tsoa, orÂ Fastify â€” Using popular TS tooling to build your API? Our guides show you how to go from code to best in class OpenAPI specs &Â SDKs.

Speakeasy sponsor

Remix â¤ï¸ Vite: Remix 2.2 Introduces Vite Support â€” Remix is a popular full-stack JavaScript framework that began as a paid product, but has been open source for two years now. If you found Remixâ€™s compilation approach opaque before, we have great news: â€œWith Vite, Remix is no longer a compiler. Remix itself is just a Vite plugin.â€ This post tells the fullÂ story.

Cattori and Dalgleish (Remix)

  • ğŸ—³ The folks behind the State of JavaScript survey have unveiled a new State of React survey to take. As with their other surveys, you get to test your knowledge as well as provide useful insights.

  • ğŸ” Shadow is a new, experimental browser engine built in JavaScript itself. It renders its output in your usual browser using an HTML canvas. Source code.

  • ğŸ” GitHub is scanning all public npm packages for leaked secrets. Note that if secrets are found, the provider associated with those secrets isÂ notified.

  • â„ï¸ WinterJS is a new JS Service Workers server, powered by Rust &Â SpiderMonkey.

  • ğŸ¥ Uh-oh, it's Flappy Bird implemented in TypeScript types.

RELEASES:

  • Astro 3.4 â€“ The Web framework gains page partials, a new experimental dev overlay, andÂ more.

  • Visual Studio Code October 2023 â€“ A couple of minor enhancements to the JS debugger, and Copilot Chat (if you have GitHub Copilot) can now provide better answers because it's sent implementation details behind the symbols youÂ mention.

  • jQuery 4.0 is 100% feature complete but it's not released just yet.. but we know youÂ can'tÂ wait. Ditto for Angular 17 â€“ more on thatÂ soon.

  • Rollup 4.2, Cypress 13.4, Ember.js 5.4, Stencil 4.7

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Speeding Up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Tailwind CSS â€” Marvinâ€™s ongoing journey to improve our ecosystem by finding low-hanging performance-bearing fruit continues with a look at how the architecture of Tailwind CSS could beÂ tuned.

Marvin Hagemeist

A New Way to Bring Garbage Collected Languages Efficiently to WebAssembly â€” WasmGC is a new and promising way to implement GC languages in WebAssembly and itâ€™s now enabled by default inÂ Chrome.

Alon Zakai (V8)

Generally Awesome UI Components For Project Management andÂ Scheduling â€” Level up your UX with advanced data grids, calendars, schedulers, and GanttÂ charts.

Bryntum sponsor

â–¶Â Â Your Website Does Not Need JavaScript â€” An hour long talk in which Amy builds a completely static website â€” using a collection of HTML and CSS files with no tracking, no scripting, no servers, and no third-partyÂ resources.

Amy Kapernick

Building a Generic RSS Parser Service with Cloudflare Workers â€” Ray walks through various iterations and improvements in trying to build an RSS parser that can work in the WorkersÂ environment.

Raymond Camden

Can Next.js Handle 5000 Pages? â€” Christian set out to push both Next.js and AWS AmplifyÂ hard. A goodÂ read.

Christian Nwamba

ğŸ—£Â Is Express Still the 'De-Facto' Choice for Building Node.jsÂ Webapps?
Hacker News

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Svelte Flow: Node-Based UI for Svelte â€” From the creators of React Flow comes a Svelte version in the shape of a customizable Svelte component for building node-based editors and interactive diagrams. Check out theÂ examples.

webkid GmbH

Docusaurus 3.0: Meta's Static Site Generator â€” Docusaurus is a popular React-powered tool aimed at building documentation sites, though it handles more general sites too. v3 features an upgrade to MDX v3, React 18, Mermaid v10, and essentially updatesÂ everything.

SÃ©bastien Lorber

Get Logged Values Right Where You Need Them: In Your Editor â€” Simply start your editor, and your development server/test runner in watch mode, and see values next to your code. No setupÂ required.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Hotkey 2.2: Declarative Keyboard Shortcuts for HTML â€” Set a data-hotkey attribute on your elements to quickly add keyboard shortcuts. v2.2 improves Mac alt/optionÂ support.

GitHub

Is Text or Binary? 7.0 â€” This library first tries to determine from a filename if the contents of the associated file are likely to be binary or text. Failing that, it can then look at the actual data to figure itÂ out.

Bevry

<browser-window>: A Web Component to Create Pretend Browser Windows on the Web â€” A lightweight themed zero-dependency web component wrapper to emulate a Safari-like browser window within a Web page. The page full of demos might give you some ideas for itsÂ use.

Zach Leatherman

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics to Your JavaScript App inÂ Minutes

FusionAuth sponsor

lossless-json: Parse JSON Without Losing Numeric Information â€” JSON.parse can trip over when it comes to large numbers, so this library parses numeric values not as regular numbers but in a lightweight lossless way keeping the value as aÂ string.

Jos de Jong

Vueform: An Open Source Form Framework for Vue.js â€” This has been around for a while but is now MIT licensed. Its ancillary form builder app stays commercial, but isn't mandatory for using the library. GitHubÂ repo.

Vueform

  • sweetalert2 v11.9 â€“ Customizable, accessible replacement forÂ alert()

  • YouTube.js 7.0 â€“ Wrapper around YouTube's internal API.

  • eslint-plugin-unicorn 49 â€“ Over 100 useful ESLint rules.

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œIf it doesn't work, it doesn't matter how fast it doesn'tÂ work.â€

___
Mich Ravera

ğŸ’›Â And something else we love

Val Town 3.0: A Social Way to Write and Deploy TypeScript â€” â€œIf GitHub Gists Could Run, and AWS Lambda Were Funâ€ is a fantastic description for this online platform where you write tiny bite size functions (â€˜valâ€™s) to be run in V8 isolates. You can connect them together, schedule them, serve them up over HTTP, and more. Version 3 is a big jump for the platform, adding JSX support, more standardized JavaScript approaches to solving problems, and the ability to edit and run your â€˜valsâ€™ locally.

Steve Krouse

items.title: Web Components forever?
items.content:
#â€‹660 â€” October 26, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Transformers.js 2.7: ML for the Web, Now with Text-to-Speech â€” Transformers.js provides access to machine learning models directly in the browser for all sorts of tasks and v2.7 introduces audio generation (liveÂ demo.) The Web Speech API remains the natural choice for this task for now, but the ML approach will only continue to offer greater opportunities overÂ time.

Joshua Lochner

ğŸ”¥ Â Web Components Will Outlive Your JavaScript Framework â€” Itâ€™s a spicy opinion piece but I think Jake has earned the right after his fantastic posts on CRDTs in which he focused on using vanilla JS web components rather than a system like React. Here, he explainsÂ why.

Jake Lazaroff

ğŸ—£ Jake's post fuelled an extensive Hacker News discussion touching on everything from MDX and htmx's role, to state management and the 'shallow' nature of the Web Components API as-is.

Production Ready Postgres at Your Fingertips â€” Deploy a faster and more reliable Postgres cluster. Run in the cloud of your choice with management, backups, and production features handled for you. Get started with less than 5 minutes. TryÂ itÂ today.

Crunchy Bridge sponsor

Yarn 4.0 Released â€” Starting life as an npm alternative that resolved several of its major pain points, Yarn remains a popular choice and v4 introduces a new â€˜hardened modeâ€™ to protect you from various security issues, boasts an improved constraints engine, and has performance (almost) on par withÂ pnpm.

MaÃ«l Nison

Node v21.1 (Current) Released with ESM Detection Feature â€” â€œThe new flag --experimental-detect-module can be used to automatically run ES modules when their syntax can be detected. â€¦ We hope to make detection enabled by default in a futureÂ version..â€

MichaÃ«l Zasso

  • ğŸ¦ The React team has announced the much anticipated Server Actions and Client Actions features are now available in React Canary.

  • ğŸ“£ The Angular team is cooking up something big with Angular 17. Minko Gechev has teased a long, forthcoming release post and they're encouraging us all to set a notification for Nov 6's â–¶ï¸ live streamed 'Special Angular Event' onÂ YouTube.

  • ğŸ¨ Photopea is a neat online image editor, but there's now Vectorpea, a browser-based vector editor, a la Illustrator.

  • ğŸ¤— If you want to take initial steps into contributing to open source JavaScript projects on GitHub, verto.sh has curated a collection of projects to check out.

RELEASES:

  • p5.js 1.8 â€“ Processing-inspired creative coding environment. v1.8 has some WebGL relatedÂ improvements.

  • Node v20.9.0 (LTS) â€“ Node v20 finally becomes the newest 'active LTS' release and has the codenameÂ 'Iron.'

  • Billboard.js 3.10 â€“ Rich charting library.

  • Bun 1.0.7

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Svelte by Example: A Gentle Introduction â€” A succinct, gentle, and code-focused introduction to Svelte and SvelteKit.

Sebastian De Deyne

'Why I Won't Use Next.js' â€” From the perspective of web standards to concerns about increasing complexity, Kent C. Dodds shares his opinions on why he wonâ€™t use Next.js. Itâ€™s spicy and opinionated, but always thoughtful. (In other Kent news, heâ€™s just launched Epic Web, his new full-stack webapp developmentÂ course.)

Kent C. Dodds

Product for Engineers: A Newsletter Helping Flex Your Product Muscle â€” Subscribe to get curated advice on building great products, lessons from PostHog, and best practices of topÂ startups.

PostHog sponsor

Goodbye, Node.js Buffer â€” Given Sindre's gigantic number of libraries, he could possibly migrate half the ecosystem solo.. ğŸ˜ but he sets out a case for discouraging the use of Buffer in favor of the cross-platform Uint8Array, and explains how to make theÂ move.

Sindre Sorhus

Changing Colors in an SVG Element with CSS and JavaScript â€” Almost everything inside an inline SVG image is up for modification using CSS andÂ JS.

Kirupa Chinnathambi

ES Module Imports in Node.js and the Browser â€” Just a quick example/handy recap of the basicÂ setup.

Eli Bendersky

Playing with the Gamepad API â€” One developerâ€™s attempt to get JavaScript games ready to use controllers in theÂ browser.
Alvaro Montoro

Using Cloudflare's AI Workers to Add Translations to PDFs
Raymond Camden

â–¶Â Â My Problem with Using TypeScript in 2023
James Q Quick

â–¶Â Â Vue 3 for Beginners â€” A mega three hour workshop onÂ YouTube.
Allan Jeremy

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Radix Vue 1.0: Unstyled, Accessible Components for Vue.js â€” An unofficial Vue port of the popular Radix UI component library. GitHubÂ repo.

zernonia et al.

React Magic Motion: Automagical Animation for Components â€” Built on top of Framer Motion so you get all of its features, but with opinionated, default transitions for childÂ components.

Etesam Ansari

No-Code Machine Learning on the Simplest Development PlatformÂ â€‘Â Catalyst

QuickML â€“ Catalyst by Zoho sponsor

background-removal: Remove Image Backgrounds inÂ JS â€” Wipe away backgrounds in both Node and the browser (so thereâ€™s a live demo) without relying on third party services. It does use a large pre-trained model to do this, however, and is GPL licensed, so your mileage mayÂ vary.

imgâ€¤ly

Wireit: Makes npm/Yarn Scripts Smarter, More Efficient â€” Working with npm run and not replacing it, Wireit extends your scripts with features like result caching, parallelization, and re-running onÂ changes.

Google

  • ğŸ“ˆ Perspective 2.6 â€“ Data visualization and analytics component, suited for streaming or large dataset use cases, with a mildly hypnotic, rapidly updating homepage (above) â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

  • ğŸ“‹ Clipboardy 4.0 â€“ Access the system clipboard from Node and browsers.

  • npm-publish 3.0 â€“ GitHub Action to publish packages toÂ npm.

  • http-fake-backend 5.0 â€“ Build a fake backend by providingÂ JSON.

  • Opal 1.8 â€“ Ruby to JavaScript transpiler.

Never Stop Learning and Work #LikeABosch â€” At Bosch, you always keep growing. Upskill yourself into countless new roles, positions and opportunities. LearnÂ more.

Bosch sponsor

  • MDX 3.0 â€“ Use JSX in Markdown documents.

  • Size Limit 10 â€“ Performance budget tool for JavaScript.

  • Jotai 2.5 â€“ Atomic global React state management.

  • Protobuf-ES 1.4 â€“ Protocol Buffers for JS/TS.

  • NodeBB 3.5 â€“ Node.js-powered forum system.

QUOTABLE:

â€œThere are two methods in software design. One is to make the program so simple, there are obviously no errors. The other is to make it so complicated, there are no obviousÂ errors.â€

___
Tony Hoare, inventor of the quicksort algorithm.
